comments:
Oops, I guess the enter button defaults to "Commit"

I ran into the problem when optimizing stepping in DSF.  I simply pressed the F5 key for step-into and held it down.  The exception came pretty quickly.  The source I used is attached, and the trace is below.

An internal error occurred during: "Retrieving Children".

java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: Index: 5, Size: 5
at java.util.ArrayList.RangeCheck(ArrayList.java:546)
at java.util.ArrayList.get(ArrayList.java:321)
at org.eclipse.cdt.debug.internal.core.model.CThread.updateStackFrames(CThread.java:271)
at org.eclipse.cdt.debug.internal.core.model.CThread.computeStackFrames(CThread.java:193)
at org.eclipse.cdt.debug.internal.core.model.CThread.computeStackFrames(CThread.java:309)
at org.eclipse.cdt.debug.internal.core.model.CThread.getStackFrames(CThread.java:119)
at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.elements.adapters.ThreadContentAdapter.getChildren(ThreadContentAdapter.java:23)
at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.viewers.provisional.AsynchronousContentAdapter.computeChildren(AsynchronousContentAdapter.java:105)
at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.viewers.provisional.AsynchronousContentAdapter$1.run(AsynchronousContentAdapter.java:42)
at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)

Created an attachment (id=48778)
Source for the example.
The array of frames returned by the "getStackFrames" method of the "Thread" class is corrupted.

The problem is caused by passing a wrong argument to the backend. The stack frame depth is passed to the "getCDIStackFrames(int lowFrame, int highFrame)" method of the CThread class instead of passing the high frame level.
Applied fix to the HEAD.
*** Bug 100259 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
